Shader

This is the presentation of the results from the shader following Phong shading algorithm implemented by Siqi Zuo and me.

The parameters to generate each image are implemented with the following flags

  • -pl x y z r g b : set a point light at (x,y,z) with color (r,g,b)
  • -dl x y z r g b : set a directional light at (x,y,z) with color (r,g,b). For both point light and directional light, the intensity is captured in the magnitude of the (r,g,b) values
  • -ks a b c : set a specular coefficient
  • -ka a b c : set a ambient coefficient
  • -kd a b c : set a diffuse coefficient
  • -sp p : the specular exponent used in Phong shading model
  • -spu pu : the u component in anisotropic specular coefficient
  • -spv pv : the v component in anisotropic specular coefficient
  • -o filename : save the image to a .bmp file with filename

Some cool stuff to begin with



from top to bottom:

  • "Debate": created with ./as1 -kd 0.7 1 1.2 -ks 1.2 1 0.7 -pl 1 1 -2 2 0.5 1 -pl -1 -1 -2 0 0.5 2 -spv 0.01 -spu 100 -pl 0 0 2 1 1 1
  • "Sunrise": created with ./as1 -kd 0.7 1 1.2 -ks 1.2 1 0.7 -pl 1 1 -2 1 0.5 0.1 -pl -1 -1 -2 0.1 0.5 1
  • "Eye": created with ./as1 -kd 0.7 1 1.2 -ks 1.2 1 0.7 -pl 0 0 -1 0.5 0.5 0.5 -pl 0 0 2 0.8 0.8 0.8 -sp 3
  • "Poles": created with ./as1 -kd 0.7 1 1.2 -ks 1.2 1 0.7 -pl 1 1 -2 2 0.5 0 -pl -1 -1 -2 0.3 2 1 -sp 10

The Required Deliverables

  1. Diffuse only with single light source

    ./as1 -kd 2 1 2 -dl -1 -1 -1 0.5 0.5 1.5

  2. Specular only with single directial light, light shines towards (0,-1,-1), the 'forehead' of the sphere is lit. Notice that as sp increases, the light in the middle shrinks in size

    ./as1 -ks 2 1 2 -dl 0 -1 -1 0.5 0.5 1.5 -sp 1

    ./as1 -ks 2 1 2 -dl 0 -1 -1 0.5 0.5 1.5 -sp 5

    ./as1 -ks 2 1 2 -dl 0 -1 -1 0.5 0.5 1.5 -sp 10

  3. Specular only with single point light

    4. Specular only with single point light, light is placed at (0,-1,1), the 'foot' of the sphere. Notice that as sp increases, the light in the middle shrinks in size

    ./as1 -ks 2 1 2 -pl 0 -1 1 0.5 0.5 1.5 -sp 1

    ./as1 -ks 2 1 2 -pl 0 -1 1 0.5 0.5 1.5 -sp 5

    ./as1 -ks 2 1 2 -pl 0 -1 1 0.5 0.5 1.5 -sp 10

  4. Specular and diffuse

    5. Diffuse reflects primarily red light, specular reflects primarily blue light, to create the distinction between two types of reflection

    ./as1 -kd 2 1 0.5 -ks 0.5 1 2 -dl -1 -1 -1 0.5 0.5 1.5

  5. Anistropic specularity

    6. Using u,v coefficients to achieve anisotropic reflection. If we keep u fixed as 1, and vary v from 1 to 5 to 10, we can observe the light band gets widened.

    ./as1 -ks 0.5 1 2 -dl -1 -1 -1 0.5 0.5 1.5 -spu 1 -spv 1

    ./as1 -ks 0.5 1 2 -dl -1 -1 -1 0.5 0.5 1.5 -spu 1 -spv 5

    ./as1 -ks 0.5 1 2 -dl -1 -1 -1 0.5 0.5 1.5 -spu 1 -spv 10

    Just like v controls the horizontal broadening of the light band, we can vary u to elongate the light band. The below two examples shows the extreme cases.

    left: ./as1 -ks 0.5 1 2 -dl -1 -1 -1 0.5 0.5 1.5 -spu 0.01 -spv 100

    right: ./as1 -ks 0.5 1 2 -dl -1 -1 -1 0.5 0.5 1.5 -spu 100 -spv 0.01

  6. Multiple light sources

    7. Multiple light sources

    Four direction lights placed at four corners of the scene, shining towards the sphere. ./as1 -kd 2 1 0.5 -ks 0.5 1 2 -dl 1 1 -1 0.1 0.1 0.1 -dl -1 1 -1 0.1 0.1 0.1 -dl 1 -1 -1 0.1 0.1 0.1 -dl -1 -1 -1 0.1 0.1 0.1 -sp 10

    Two point lights placed at the diagonal of the scene, one behind and one in front. ./as1 -kd 2 1 0.5 -ks 0.5 1 2 -pl -1 -1 -1 0.5 0.5 0.5 -pl 1 1 1 0.5 0.5 0.5

    Three point light shining before the sphere. ./as1 -kd 2 1 0.5 -ks 0.5 1 2 -pl 0 1 1 0.5 0.5 0.5 -pl 0.8 -0.5 1 0.5 0.5 0.5 -pl -0.8 -0.5 1 0.5 0.5 0.5 -sp 5 -ka 0.1 0.1 0.1

Extra Credits

  • We implemented image saving using the C++ bitmap_image library. Use '-o' flag followed by filename to save file

  • Beside sphere, we also allows user to shade a hyperboloid, use flag '-hyper' to shade a hyperboloid instead of a sphere. This are some examples.
